detail.content: Masterclass in Television: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Rita and Burton Goldberg Department of Dramatic Writing About the Program/Admissions Admissions Student Life Course Offerings News & Events Work of Writing Students Screenplay Showcase Fellowships/Contests Script Bank Sloan Winners Admin & Faculty Alumni Internships Contact  home > Dramatic Writing        Masterclass in Television  DWPG.1047 Lect 3 Credits For TV concentrates and non-concentrates with at least 2 TV courses, Masterclasses focus on Topics. Students work intensely to develop scripts from premis to pages.    Topics: Sketch Writing: This is a sketch writing workshop class. A survey of sketch genres and approaches will be integrated with writing assignments and rewriting of one’s own sketches: both privately and collaboratively. The goal is for each student to emerge from the class with several polished sketches. For this class, it helps to have a good sense of humor that you want to get even better at putting down on the page. There will be a lot of group critiquing and occasionally group rewriting. So it helps to stop thinking that your first draft is perfect. Because it isn’t. This can be a pretty wild class, so it also helps to never think that comedy can go “too far.” The course may have a guest lecturer.    Topics: Late Night Comedy Writing: Joke-writers aren't allowed to wait until they feel funny. This intensive introduction to the craft of writing topical jokes exposes students to the rigors of producing news-driven jokes and comedy pieces on demand. Students will be required to keep abreast of the news and come to class prepared to write jokes and desk-pieces on subjects that the instructor will select. Students will create material appropriate for different programs and hosts, from “The Daily Show with Jon Stewart” to “Late Night with David Letterman.” Occasional guest speakers from late-night comedy shows will critique students’ materials. By the end of the class, students will have compiled a joke packet that may be used to seek work in the field upon graduation.     Topics: Writing for Children's Television: Television aimed at children and teens continues to provide perennial entertainment around the world. How do these series continue to endure, both in a practical and creative sense? Explore writing for “kids’ animated” programs: for different age groups, animation and live-action, narrative and non-fiction, and across the genres of action, comedy, and educational programming. Students will analyze series bibles, premises, outlines, and scripts for existing shows and ultimately develop a spec from concept to script.    Topics: One Hour Drama: In this class students conceive and complete a full-length play of at least 85 pages. Or, they may choose to do a page one (i.e. complete) rewrite of their full-length play from Playwriting I.    Topics: Half Hour Comedy Pilots This class is for the writing of half-hour comedy pilots, live-action or animation, from premise to pages. This is not just a class for TV Concentrates. It is intended as a TV class for non-TV Concentrates who have had two TV classes and desire a high-level TV comedy workshop before graduation. Masterclass in Television: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Rita and Burton Goldberg Department of Dramatic Writing About the Program/Admissions Admissions Student Life Course Offerings News & Events Work of Writing Students Screenplay Showcase Fellowships/Contests Script Bank Sloan Winners Admin & Faculty Alumni Internships Contact  home > Dramatic Writing        Masterclass in Television  DWPG.1047 Lect 3 Credits For TV concentrates and non-concentrates with at least 2 TV courses, Masterclasses focus on Topics. Students work intensely to develop scripts from premis to pages.    Topics: Sketch Writing: This is a sketch writing workshop class. A survey of sketch genres and approaches will be integrated with writing assignments and rewriting of one’s own sketches: both privately and collaboratively. The goal is for each student to emerge from the class with several polished sketches. For this class, it helps to have a good sense of humor that you want to get even better at putting down on the page. There will be a lot of group critiquing and occasionally group rewriting. So it helps to stop thinking that your first draft is perfect. Because it isn’t. This can be a pretty wild class, so it also helps to never think that comedy can go “too far.” The course may have a guest lecturer.    Topics: Late Night Comedy Writing: Joke-writers aren't allowed to wait until they feel funny. This intensive introduction to the craft of writing topical jokes exposes students to the rigors of producing news-driven jokes and comedy pieces on demand. Students will be required to keep abreast of the news and come to class prepared to write jokes and desk-pieces on subjects that the instructor will select. Students will create material appropriate for different programs and hosts, from “The Daily Show with Jon Stewart” to “Late Night with David Letterman.” Occasional guest speakers from late-night comedy shows will critique students’ materials. By the end of the class, students will have compiled a joke packet that may be used to seek work in the field upon graduation.     Topics: Writing for Children's Television: Television aimed at children and teens continues to provide perennial entertainment around the world. How do these series continue to endure, both in a practical and creative sense? Explore writing for “kids’ animated” programs: for different age groups, animation and live-action, narrative and non-fiction, and across the genres of action, comedy, and educational programming. Students will analyze series bibles, premises, outlines, and scripts for existing shows and ultimately develop a spec from concept to script.    Topics: One Hour Drama: In this class students conceive and complete a full-length play of at least 85 pages. Or, they may choose to do a page one (i.e. complete) rewrite of their full-length play from Playwriting I.    Topics: Half Hour Comedy Pilots This class is for the writing of half-hour comedy pilots, live-action or animation, from premise to pages. This is not just a class for TV Concentrates. It is intended as a TV class for non-TV Concentrates who have had two TV classes and desire a high-level TV comedy workshop before graduation. Masterclass in Television Writing: Late Night Comedy Writing: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Rita and Burton Goldberg Department of Dramatic Writing About the Program/Admissions Admissions Student Life Course Offerings News & Events Work of Writing Students Screenplay Showcase Fellowships/Contests Script Bank Sloan Winners Admin & Faculty Alumni Internships Contact  home > Dramatic Writing        Masterclass in Television Writing: Late Night Comedy Writing  DWPG.1047 Lec 3 Credits PREREQUISITES:: A love of news and a desire to write jokes about it.    PREREQUISITE 2: A love of comedy.(Preference will be given to students who have taken a comedy class, and/or have comedy experience.)Joke-writers aren't allowed to wait until they feel funny.    This intensive introduction to the craft of writing topical jokes exposes students to the rigors of producing news-driven jokes and comedy pieces on demand. Students will be required to keep abreast of the news and come to class prepared to write jokes and desk-pieces on subjects that the instructor will select. Students will create material appropriate for different programs and hosts, from “The Daily Show with Jon Stewart” to “Late Night with David Letterman.” Occasional guest speakers from late-night comedy shows will critique students material. By the end of the class, students will have compiled a joke packet that may be used to seek work in the field upon graduation.
